| Thinking...

Certainly! Here's a small script that uses regular expressions (regex) to extract the desired information from the provided text:

```python
import re

text = "\nThank U | Alanis Morissette | Gratitude | 1998 | Rock | Alternative Rock | Reflection | The song 'Thank U' is a beautiful celebration of the power of gratitude and its ability to transform our lives. Morissette's lyrics acknowledge the difficulties and struggles we face but then shift focus to all of the reasons we have to be grateful. The song is a powerful reminder to appreciate the good things in our lives and to be thankful for those people who have helped us along the way. The song's themes of thankfulness, reflection, and transformation closely align with the gratitude strength, which celebrates our ability to recognize and appreciate the good things in our lives, even in the face of adversity.| https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OAvmLDkAgAM"

pattern = r"\n(.+) \| (.+) \| (.+) \| (\d{4}) \| (.+) \| (.+) \| (.+) \| (.+)\| (.+)"
match = re.match(pattern, text)

if match:
    song_name = match.group(1)
    artist_name = match.group(2)
    character_strength = match.group(3)
    year = match.group(4)
    genre = match.group(5)
    style = match.group(6)
    tags = match.group(7)
    why_chosen = match.group(8)
    youtube_url = match.group(9)

    # Print the extracted information
    print("Song Name:", song_name)
    print("Artist Name:", artist_name)
    print("Character Strength:", character_strength)
    print("Year:", year)
    print("Genre:", genre)
    print("Style:", style)
    print("Tags:", tags)
    print("Why Chosen:", why_chosen)
    print("YouTube URL:", youtube_url)
```

This script uses the `re.match()` function to find a match based on the provided regex pattern. It then extracts the desired information using the `group()` method of the match object. Finally, it prints the extracted information.

Note: The script assumes that the provided text follows the specified format, and it only extracts information for a single song.

Can you write a small script that use regex to extract the text inside the "Text" argument
